did.abstract: A Congregational church was officially formed in Halifax in 1734, with 53 founding members. A second meeting house was built in 1852. In 1842 a Ladies Sewing Circle was organized and continued to be central to church life. The Halifax Congregational Church is now a member of the United Church of Christ, and continues to serve the community today. This collection consists of early administrative records for the Congregational Church and the associated parish in Halifax.

bioghist.head: Historical Note
bioghist.p: The land which would become Halifax, Mass. was originally part of West Precinct of Plymouth, which included Plympton, Carver, and Wareham. In 1731, residents in northern Plympton lobbied successfully for permission to hold their own religious meeting in the home of Deacon Robert Waterman. The following year, local landowner John Bryant deeded a plot to the religious society's proprietors for the erection of a meeting house. In October of 1734 a church was officially formed by order of an ecclesiastical council, and its covenant signed by 22 male and 31 female members. Rev. John Cotton was the church's first minister, ordained in 1735 and remaining in the position for 20 years. Subsequent early pastors included Rev. William Patten (1757-1765), Rev. Ephraim Briggs (1767-1799), and Rev. Abel Richmond (1800-1832), who was ousted after a 33-year pastorate due to disagreements with parishioners.

A Sunday school was founded in 1736, possibly the first such establishment in North America. In the 1750s the meeting house was deemed too small to accommodate the growing population. The building was split in half and expanded by 16 feet in the middle. In addition to being a locus for both town and church business, the meeting house was also used for the storage of munitions and gunpowder during the latter part of the 18th century. In 1821 a steeple and bell were built and installed via funds raised from the sale of pews. The expanded first meeting house continued to serve the needs of the church until the early 1850s, when it was sold to the town to be used as a town hall. Though remarkably long-lived, the building was destroyed in a fire in 1907.

After the dismission of Rev. Abel Richmond in 1832, Rev. Eldridge Howe was invited to the ministry and accepted. A large portion of the congregation still professed loyalty to Rev. Richmond. In 1834, 15 members seceded from the church. This was followed by numerous other secessions over the following year, resulting in a significant decline in overall membership, to about half of its former size. The remaining congregants were unable to pay Rev. Howe's salary to his satisfaction, and he tendered his resignation in late 1835. The following decades were typified by short supply ministries, a notable exception being the 11-year pastorate of Rev. Timothy Brainerd from 1855-1866.

In 1842 a Ladies' "Missionary Sewing Circle" was officially organized, with the intent to provide clothing for a missionary station in Canada. The group changed names several times in subsequent years and was also known as the Ladies Sewing Circle, the Ladies Benevolent Society, and the Halifax Benevolent Society. Their mission also expanded to include general fundraising for the church and other charitable causes. Despite changes in name and emphasis, this women's group essentially persisted throughout the 19th and 20th centuries and remained an important part of church life.

In 1852 a second meeting house was built for the Church's use, slightly to the west of the original building. It was erected at a cost of $5,200 and was dedicated on December 7, 1852 with its dedicatory sermon delivered by the Rev. Charles Porter from Plymouth. In 1921, during Sunday service, a violent wind gust caused the steeple to collapse and the spire to fall into an unoccupied pew. The mortgage for the church was paid in full in 1978, and subsequently burned ceremonially in a special service, a popular tradition at the time. The Halifax Congregational Church is now a member of the United Church of Christ, and continues to serve the community today.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This collection consists of early administrative records for the Congregational Church and the associated parish in Halifax, as well as membership records, records of Ladies' societies associated with the church, and manuscript historical narratives. Member records include a large number of marriage intentions from the early to mid 1800s.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This collection has been arranged into four series, listed below. Except within the membership series, records have been arranged in chronological order, by start date. Within the membership series, records have been grouped by topics, and further divided by either alphabetical or chronological order.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains the administrative records of the church and parish in Halifax, including three bound records books. The series includes meeting minutes, officer lists, financial records, ecclesiastical council records, correspondence, and other administrative documentation.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This bound volume of church records contains the earliest administrative documentation of the Church of Christ in Halifax. It includes the church's confession of faith, the earliest covenant, meeting minutes, baptisms, member lists, and disciplinary records.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This file contains loose records documenting lists of church officers, including deacons and clergy.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This folder contains loose financial records, including itemized receipts to and from various individuals for everyday expenses, and Rev. Abel Richmond's receipts for payments to Rhode Island College.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This bound parish record book primarily contains meeting minutes, as well as policy documents, copies of deeds, and copies of correspondence.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This bound volume of parish treasury records contains financial ledgers with lists of subscribers and rates.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This folder contains loose records containing the results of ecclesiastical councils, which were primarily called to settle disputes within individual churches, as well as for the ordinations of new ministers.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This folder contains loose records of meeting minutes for both the church and parish of Halifax, which include legal warnings, synopses of meetings, and votes on various issues.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This bound volume contains records for the Congregational Church in Halifax (referred to only as the "Church in Halifax"). The volume includes meeting minutes, baptisms, admissions, member lists, articles of faith, the church covenant, and ecclesiastical council minutes.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This folder contains loose correspondence, including letters relating to church disputes, missionary society correspondence and newsletter items, and invitations to ordination councils.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This folder contains two black and white photographic prints depicting the sanctuary of the second meeting house and the downstairs sunday school room, an engraving of the Halifax town hall, and a missionary card depicting the ship "Morning Star".

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This folder contains 2 loose records relating to the Pilgrim Conference at Halifax and an invitation to a the Boston Council of Congregational Churches.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This folder contains loose records relating to church policy, including undated early copies of the church's articles of faith and covenant, as well as a constitution document from the National Council of the Congregational Churches of the United States.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains the membership records of the church in Halifax, and includes lists of admissions to the church, formal correspondence relating to dismissions and transfers to and from other churches, a large number of official marriage intention documents from the 1800s, and several relations of faith by potential members.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This folder contains official correspondence between churches, relating to the transfer and dismission of members to and from the Congregational Church in Halifax. It includes documentation relating to members with surnames A-H.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This folder contains official correspondence between churches, relating to the transfer and dismission of members to and from the Congregational Church in Halifax. It includes documentation relating to members with surnames I-Z.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This folder contains marriage intentions, official documents recording marriages in Halifax and surrounding areas. The intentions record the names of the betrothed and their location, and are typically signed by the town clerk. Records are arranged alphabetically by the groom's surname.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains handwritten historical accounts, mainly by Halifax local Ignatius Thomson. In his voluminous manuscripts he describes the historical events leading up to the foundation of Halifax as well as a history of the town and region. There are also a small number of undated handwritten historical notes.

scopecontent.p: This manuscript volume contains a broad-ranging historical narrative focusing on the history of Halifax. A tte-bche financial ledger is also present at the back of the volume.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series consists of four record books and one folder of loose documents relating to various iterations of the Ladies Society of the Halifax Congregational Church. The record books are largely sequential with occassional gaps and changes in name.

scopecontent.p: This record book of the Ladies Benevolent Society contains a preamble with the organization's mission statement, meeting minutes, lists of officers, lists of subscribers, and financial records.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This volume contains the records for the Ladies Benevolent Society, including meeting minutes, officer lists, financial records, and records of charitable contributions including collections for Union soldiers during the Civil War.
